newsitem.title: USA: Judge orders Prudential document destruction probe.
newsitem.headline: Judge orders Prudential document destruction probe.

text.p: A U.S. district judge said he wanted additional information about the destruction of documents at a Prudential Insurance Co of America sales office in Massachusetts before deciding whether to impose sanctions.

U.S. district judge Alfred Wolin in Newark, N.J., ordered Melvyn Weiss, one of the attorney's representing policyholders in the class action against Prudential, to conduct the investigation and issue a report to the court by December 27.
Wolin said the court will then "very promptly" issue an opinion on the request that sanctions be imposed on Prudential.
Prudential on Monday said it had discovered the document destruction during a routine compliance examination of its Cambridge, Mass., office.
Prudential said it has dismissed John Breedlove, the managing director of the office, and called the document destruction deplorable and a clear violation of the company's policy.
This incident follows several other document destruction incidents. Prudential in August fired a senior vice president for failing to enforce company directives about preserving documents.
Policyholder attorneys are concerned about the destruction of documents because they could be relevant to policyholder claims in the class action against Prudential for improper sales practices.
Policyholders must decide by December 19 whether to participate in the proposed class action settlement.
A hearing on the fairness of the proposed settlement is scheduled for January 21.
In that settlement, Prudential agreed to pay at least $410 million to settle lawsuits by policyholders claiming they were victims of deceptive sales practices.
Prudential earlier in the year also agreed to pay a record $35 million fine and reimburse customers nationwide as part of a separate multi-state settlement.
